File name: FindMedian.java

This is a Java program that can calculate the median of a set of numbers. The median is the middle value when the numbers are sorted in ascending or descending order. If the set has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle values.

To use the program, create an array of doubles and pass it to the findMedian method, which returns the median as a double. If the array is empty, the program returns NaN (Not a Number). If the array has only one element, the program returns that element.

The program uses a quickselect algorithm to find the median in O(n) time on average, where n is the length of the array. This algorithm is based on the partition routine of the quicksort algorithm and provides a linear-time solution for selecting the kth smallest element in an unsorted array. The program also uses a random pivot to achieve a good expected performance even for worst-case inputs.

This program can be used in various contexts where the median of a dataset is needed, such as in statistics, finance, or data analysis. It can also serve as a learning resource for understanding the quickselect algorithm and its implementation in Java.

Here's a possible rephrased version:

To find the number of trailing zeros in the binary representation of a given positive integer, we need to count the number of consecutive zeroes appearing at the end (i.e., on the right) of the binary string. This can be done by dividing the integer by successive powers of 2 and checking if the remainder is zero or not. If the remainder is zero, we have found a trailing zero and can continue with the next power of 2. If the remainder is non-zero, we stop and return the count of trailing zeros found so far.
